titleStmt.title: Design of a low density refractory high entropy alloy in non-equiatomic W-Mo-Cr-Ti-Al system

affiliation.orgName: Department of Metallurgical and Materials Engineering
Department of Metallurgical and Materials Engineering
Department of Metallurgical and Materials Engineering

analytic.title: Design of a low density refractory high entropy alloy in non-equiatomic W-Mo-Cr-Ti-Al system

biblStruct.note: Received 13 May 2020; Received in revised form 6 July 2020; Accepted 7 July 2020

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

textClass.keywords: Refractory high entropy alloy Non-equiatomic Low density Solid solution Vacuum arc melting Hardness Compression strength

div.p: A new refractory high entropy alloy (RHEA) with non-equiatomic composition of W 10 Mo 27 Cr 21 Ti 22 Al 20 was designed based on empirical rules and CALPHAD approach. Calculated results showed that W 10 Mo 27 Cr 21 Ti 22 Al 20 RHEA had lower density and higher melting temperature than that of equiatomic alloy. The designed alloy was prepared by vacuum arc melting then the crystal structure, microstructure, chemical composition, density, hardness and compressive strength had been evaluated. The alloy exhibited a BCC solid solution as major phase with typical dendritic microstructures. The experimental results confirmed calculated results, suggesting a BCC solid solution phase. The density of the alloy was 7.48 g/cm 3 , which was approximately close to the calculated value, 7.61 g/cm 3 . However, the measured hardness value (511 kg/mm 2 ) was significantly higher than the calculated value (125 kg/mm 2 ), indicating the effect of solid solution strengthening. This alloy had compressive yield strengths of 1245 MPa at room temperature, 510 MPa at 600 • C, 201 MPa at 1000 • C and 105 MPa at 1200 • C. Compressive strain of the alloy was limited at room temperature, but it increased significantly to above 60% at 1000 • C and 1200 • C. Comparing with four conventional superalloys Inconel 718, Waspaloy, Hastaloy X and Haynes 230, the studied RHEA shows lower density and superior high-temperature yield strength.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: High entropy alloys (HEA) are defined as solid solution alloys that contain at least five principal elements, in which all the atomic concentrations are between 5% and 35%. HEAs have significantly higher mixing entropy than conventional alloys, which increases the stability of solid solution compared to intermetallic phases [1][2][3].

The mixing entropy of the alloy is maximized when its constituent elements are in equiatomic ratio. Hence, major studies in this field are focused on the design of HEAs containing elements with equal or nearequal atomic ratios [4][5][6][7]. However, an increasing number of studies have revealed that formation of solid solution phase in HEAs does not depend solely on the maximization of mixing entropy through equiatomic ratios of elements [8,9]. In addition to mixing entropy, ΔS mix , some other empirical parameters have expressed to predict the formation of solid solutions phase in HEAs. The most common parameters are: the mixing enthalpy, ΔH mix , the atomic-size difference, δ, and the relative contributions of the mixing enthalpy and the mixing entropy, Ω [10][11][12][13][14]. Considering these parameters, the solid solution phase can also be formed in non-equiatomic systems due to the contribution of parameters additional to the ΔS mix . Therefore, optimizing the composition based on non-equiatomic systems seems to be necessary to achieve new solid solution phase HEAs with desired properties.

One of the most important classes of HEAs is refractory high entropy alloys (RHEAs) based on refractory metals such as W, Ta, Mo and Nb with BCC structure [15][16][17]. RHEAs can be suitable for high temperature applications due to their high melting temperature. However, high density and poor high temperature oxidation resistance are the two main problems for the use of refractory metals in these alloys [18][19][20][21].

Several studies have been done to reduce the density and oxidation of HEAs by adding or replacing other elements such as aluminum and titanium [18,19,[22][23][24][25][26][27][28]. However, the optimal composition of the RHEAs containing these elements, so that the solid solution phase remains stable while reducing the density, has not been studied.

In the present study, the composition of W-Mo-Cr-Ti-Al based Refractory high entropy alloys was optimized to achieve a solid solution phase with a minimum density and maximum melting temperature. Non-equiatomic compositions can have a great potential for designing a large number of new HEAs with desired properties which would enable to overcome the limitations of HEAs design concept. On the other hand, the CALPHAD (CALculation of PHAse Diagram) method is also used as one of the most important methods for predicting the phase stability in several HEAs [29][30][31][32][33]. In this regard, combined with experimental results, the CALPHAD method was used to compare and validate the prediction of solid solution phase versus the empirical parameters. In the following, the properties (density, hardness and strength) of the designed alloy were studied.

div.head: Alloy design
div.p: For the alloy system, the Gibbs free energy of mixing is expressed as Equation (1):
As depicted by Equation ( 1), either decreasing the mixed enthalpy or increasing the mixed entropy can reduce the Gibbs free energy, and make the system stable.
The ΔH mix and ΔS mix parameters can be expressed as follows:
div.formula: ΔH mix = ∑ N i=1,i∕ =j 4ΔH mix ij x i x j (2
ΔS mix = -R ∑ N i=1 x i lnx i(3)
div.p: where x i (x j ), N, R and ΔH mix ij are the mole fraction of the ith (jth) element, total number of elements, gas constant (8.314 J/mol.K) and enthalpy of mixing between the ith and jth elements at equimolar concentration, respectively [10,11,14,34].

In Equation (3), only the configurational entropy of mixing is considered. Although total mixing entropy has four contributions such as configurational, vibrational, magnetic dipole, and electronic randomness, configurational entropy is dominant over other three contributions [35][36][37][38]. Gao et al. showed that configurational entropy was significantly higher than vibrational entropy of mixing and that the magnetic and electrical contributions were negligible [38]. Monte Carlo/molecular dynamics (MC/MD) simulations have also shown that the electronic and magnetic contribution is relatively small, while the vibrational contribution is significant, but still much lower than the configurational part, validating the claim that HEAs are dominated by their configurational entropy of mixing [39]. Recently, however, theoretical calculations using Ab initio density functional theory (DFT) have shown that the role of non-configurational entropies, especially vibrational entropy, is significant and can be effective in the formation of solid solution phase [40,41]. Therefore, it is suggested that in the design of new HEAs, the contribution of non-configurational entropy should be considered in predicting the formation of solid solution using theoretical calculations.

Yeh et al. [4] found that the mixing entropy of five elements with equal atomic ratio was high enough to counterbalance the mixing enthalpy in most alloy systems, and to favor the formation of solid solution phases. However, further research showed that in most of the HEAs, the maximum ΔS mix is not enough to form a solid solution phase. Therefore, in order to predict the formation of solid solution phase, the effects of both ΔS mix and ΔH mix must be considered simultaneously. Accordingly, two empirical thermo-physical parameters Ω and δ were proposed to predict the solid solution phase [10,11,[42][43][44].

The parameter Ω describes the balance between ΔS mix and ΔH mix , and δ is related to the atomic size difference in multicomponent alloys. where T m = ∑ N i=1 x i T i m is the melting temperature of HEA, r = ∑ N i=1 x i r i and r i is the atomic radius of the ith element.
div.formula: Ω = T m ΔS mix |ΔH mix |(4)
div.p: Based on the literature, Formation of solid solution phase in HEAs requires that Ω > 1.1 and δ < 6.6% [12,13,[42][43][44].
On the other hand, the density of the alloy can be estimated by equation ( 6) [45][46][47]:
div.formula: ρ = ∑ x i A i ∑ x i V i(6)
div.p: where V i = A i /ρ i is the atomic volume of element i, and A i and ρ i are the atomic weight and density of the ith element. In this research, the composition of the W-Mo-Cr-Ti-Al based alloys was optimized to achieve following three main targets simultaneously:
-Formation of a solid solution phase.

-Minimum density (less than 8 g/cm3, which is corresponded to the average density of Ni-base superalloys) [48]. -Maximum melting temperature (more than 1350 • C, which is corresponded to the average melting temperature of Ni-based superalloys) [48].

For this purpose, using MATLAB software, all compositions of W-Mo-Cr-Ti-Al quinary alloy system in the range of 5-35 at% with steps of 1 at% were obtained and for each of these compositions, the parameters of Ω, δ, ρ and Tm (Equations ( 2)-( 6)) were calculated. By applying the conditions Ω ≥ 1.1, δ ≤ 6.6%, Tm = max and ρ = min, the alloy composition that has these conditions was finally selected as the optimal alloy. CALPHAD method was used to validate the empirical results in predicting the solid solution phase. For this purpose, calculated mole fraction of stable phases was determined in the temperature range of 2500 • C-100 • C using JmatPro software (v.7.0) [44,[49][50][51][52] with Ni-based superalloys database. Although Ni-based superalloys databases were initially developed for Ni-based superalloys, they still cover many other elements used in the composition of refractory HEAs (including the elements used in our composition) [14,31,32,44,49,[53][54][55][56].

div.head: Materials and characterization
div.p: The selected alloy W 10 Mo 27 Cr 21 Ti 22 Al 20 was prepared by vacuum arc melting (VAM). High purity molten Ti was used as a getter for residual oxygen, nitrogen and hydrogen in the high vacuum chamber. All five powdered elements with a purity of over 99.5% were compacted in the form of pellets. At first, the pellets of elements Al, Ti and Cr were melted and the ingot of these elements was obtained. Then the ingot of W and Mo was obtained similarly and added to first ingot. Finally, both ingots were remelted four times to ensure the homogeneity of the alloy.

Crystal structure and phase identification were characterized using X-ray diffraction method (XRD, EXPLORER GNR analytical instrument group) with Cu Ka (λ = 0.15406 nm) radiation. The diffraction pattern was collected over a 2θ range from 20 • to 90 • with a step size of 0.01 • and step time of 2 s/step. The microstructure and the chemical compositions of the alloy were identified using a Field Emission Scanning Electron Microscope (FE-SEM, TESCAN-MIRA3) equipped with backscattering electron (BSE) and energy dispersive x-ray spectroscopy (EDS, SAMx) detector. For both XRD and SEM, the samples cut from the center part of ingot were ground with SiC abrasive papers to 2000 grit, then polished with 1 μm diamond paste, and followed by ultrasonic cleaning in ethanol and distilled water. The density of the alloy was determined by Archimedes' law. Vickers microhardness was measured according to ASTM E384-16 using a Vickers microhardness tester (BUEHLER) under a load of 500 g for 20 s. Cylindrical samples (3 mm in diameter and 5 mm in height) for compression test were cut by wire electrical discharge machining of the button-shaped ingot. Compression tests were conducted at room temperature (RT), 600, 1000 and 1200 • C in a Zwick/Roell (Z250) mechanical testing machine equipped with Zwick contact extensometer under initial stain rate of 0.001/s. For elevated temperature tests, under argon atmosphere, the samples were heated at a heating rate of 20 • C/ min, soaked at the test temperature for 10 min and then compressed to a height strain of 60% or until fracture.

div.head: Design and calculation results
div.p: In the W-Mo-Cr-Ti-Al quinary system, there are a huge number of possible alloying compositions to study the effect of the composition on the empirical parameters. In this research, after determining the optimal alloy composition, contour maps were used for demonstrating the variations of the empirical parameters with the composition in the W-Mo-Cr-Ti-Al system. On the other hand, it is not possible to display the variations of a parameter versus the composition in a quinary alloy system by 2-D contour diagram. Therefore, the atomic percent of one constituent element (e.g. Al) was kept constant and the variations of a parameter versus other four elements are plotted. Considering the Al = 20 at%, each element was fixed while the other three elements varied within the composition range of 5-35 at%. The atomic percent of fixed element was 10%, 20%, and 30%, corresponding to low, medium, and high-concentration, respectively.

Figs. 1234, respectively, show the variations of the parameters Ω, δ, ρ and T m versus the composition (at%) variations of alloys. As shown in Figs. 1 and2, most of the compositions within the range have favorable conditions for the formation of a solid solution phase (Ω > 1.1 and δ < 6.6%). On the other hand, it is known that the parameter Ω is not maximal in the equiatomic composition, so the tendency to form a solid solution phase in the non-equiatomic compositions may be greater. The contour maps in Fig. 1 illustrate that Ti has the most influence on the parameter Ω and also the lower the percentage of Ti (i.e., the higher percentage Cr, Mo and W), the parameter Ω is increased, which is mainly due to the mixing enthalpy of these elements. The mixing enthalpy of Ti with three other elements is strongly negative compared to the mixing enthalpy of Mo-W-Cr system. On the other hand, according to equation ( 4), the solid solution phase is formed if the mixing enthalpy is close to zero, so that strongly negative enthalpy of mixing leads to the formation of intermetallic compounds and positive enthalpy of mixing causes the separation of elements without forming a new phase.

Although the contour maps revealed that the trend of variations in the parameters Ω, ρ and Tm with the composition were roughly similar, however, the aim of this study was to select a composition with maximum Ω and T m and minimum ρ. Therefore, for this purpose, the composition of the alloys was optimized using the mixture design approach and the alloy composition W On the other hand, to verify and validate the prediction of phase stability for studied refractory HEAs, CALPHAD approach was used [44,[49][50][51][52]. Fig. 5(a andb) shows the predicted mole percent of stable phases during solidification for these alloys. As can be seen, the bcc solid solution phase is stable over an extremely wide temperature range. In addition to the bcc phase, the Laves phase is also formed at a temperature below 400 for W 10 Mo 27 Cr 21 Ti 22 Al 20 alloy by a solid-state reaction. The concentration of the elements in this phase, shown in Fig. 6, can be consistent with the Cr 2 (Ti,W) compound.
According to Fig. 5, the CALPHAD results confirm the empirical parameters to predict the solid solution phase in both alloys.

Although the calculation results of the empirical parameters (Table 1) show that the melting temperature (obtained from the rule of mixtures) in the equiatomic alloy is about 100 • C higher than that of optimal alloy W 10 Mo 27 Cr 21 Ti 22 Al 20 , however, the CALPHAD results in Fig. 5 show that the starting temperature of melting (Solidus temperature) in the alloy W 10 Mo 27 Cr 21 Ti 22 Al 20 is higher than the equiatomic alloy. The melting temperature obtained from the rule of mixtures is not so accurate and has two errors: first, the melting temperature is assumed to be a specified temperature while the solid solution systems have a range of melting between solidus and liquidus, and second, the interactions between the elements are not taken into account in calculating the melting temperature. Thus, the melting temperature predicted by the CALPHAD method seems to be closer to the actual experimental conditions. On the other hand, due to the wider solidus-liquidus range in equiatomic alloy, as shown in Fig. 5, the segregation level is greater than that of W 10 Mo 27 Cr 21 Ti 22 Al 20 . The lattice parameter of BCC phase in this alloy was also determined to be 3.144 Å by the Bragg's law [57]. This value was close to the calculated value of 3.153 Å by the rule of mixtures (a ave = ∑ x i a i ) [32,[58][59][60]. The XRD result is in good agreement with the results from the both empirical parameters and CALPHAD methods, which predicted the formation of solid solution as major phase.

div.head: Experimental results
div.p: SEM backscattered electron (BSE) image of the as-cast W 10 Mo 27 Cr 21 Ti 22 Al 20 RHEA is shown in Fig. 8. This image exhibits a typical dendritic microstructure with different brightness between the dendritic and interdendritic regions resulting from elemental segregation. Higher magnification image reveal the presence of a darker phase in the interdendritic regions.

The EDS analysis shows that the dendrites are enriched with heavier elements with higher melting points such as W and Mo, the interdendrites are enriched with Cr, Ti and Al, and the darker phases inside the interdendrites are heavily enriched with Cr and Ti (Table 2). These dark phases attributed to cubic Laves phase (C15) in agreement with the XRD result. The volume fraction of the Laves phase, which was obtained using image analysis in Clemex software, is about 2.3 vol% (Fig. 8(b)).

In addition, to clarify the elemental segregation in this alloy, EDS line scanning was performed on a small region. As shown in Fig. 9(a-f), the The density ρ and Vickers microhardness Hv of the alloy (both calculated and experimental) and pure metals are listed in Table 3 [55,59,[61][62][63]. The alloy has a density of 7.48 g/cm3 which is about 1.7% lower than the density calculated from equation (7). This decrease in density value may be due to the presence of porosity, which is usually present in the as-casted alloy. The experimentally-measured microhardness of the alloy was 511 kg/mm2, while using the rule of mixtures (H cal v = ∑ x i (H v ) i ((H v ) i is the microhardness of element i) the microhardness was calculated to be 125 kg/mm2 [31,32,55,58,59,64]. In fact, the calculated hardness is the average hardness value of the constituent elements of alloy. As can be seen, the microhardness of the alloy does not follow the rule of mixtures and is much higher than the calculated value. This result is mainly due to the solid solution hardening as a result of the formation of the solid solution phase, which has also been mentioned in previous studies [55,58,59,61,65].

In solid solution HEAs, various atoms randomly occupy the positions of the crystal lattice, and all atoms can be considered as solute atoms or solvent atoms (unlike solid solution in conventional alloys, which is one element as solvent). In addition, the types of atoms vary in size and properties (such as shear modulus), causing severe lattice distortion, which in turn leads to high solid-solution strengthening [66,67].

The compressive true stress-strain (σ-ε) curves of the as-cast At this temperature, the strength decreases to 172Mpa during strain softening until the test stops at ε = 60% without fracture. A considerable softening of the alloy accrued after increasing in the testing temperature to 1200 • C. At this temperature, σ 0.2 = 105Mpa, σ max = 128Mpa and then follow by a steady state flow at this stress. The sample is compressed to a strain of 60% without fracture at this temperature.

The high room temperature yield strength of this alloy compared to the yield strength of its constituent elements (Table 2) is mainly due to the solid solution strengthening. In solid-solution HEAs, the increase in strength due to solid solution (Δσ ss ) is expressed as:
div.formula: σ y = σ mix y + Δσ ss (7)
div.p: where σ y is the experimentally-measured yield strength and σ mix y is the yield strength estimated by the rule of mixtures [55,68]. According to Fig. 10 and Table 3, σ y and σ mix y are 1245 MPa and 296 MPa, respectively. Therefore, according to the equation ( 7), Δσ ss (949 MPa) has major role on the yield strength of the alloy. Fig. 11 shows the temperature dependence of the yield strength of the studied RHEA and four conventional Ni-based superalloys, Inconel 718, Waspaloy, Hastaloy X and Haynes 230 [48,[69][70][71][72][73][74]. The yield strength of the studied RHEA is higher than those of Haynes 230 and Hastaloy X at all studied temperatures and higher than those of Inconel 718 and Waspaloy at high temperatures (1000 • C and 1200 • C). In addition, density of this RHEA (7.6 g/cm 3 ) is lower than that of four conventional Ni-based superalloys (8.2-8.9 g/cm 3 ) [48,74].

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: Non-equiatomic RHEA, W 10 Mo 27 Cr 21 Ti 22 Al 20, was designed as optimum composition to achieve a solid solution phase with a minimum density and maximum melting temperature. This alloy was prepared by VAM technique and then the phase formation, microstructure, density and mechanical properties were studied. The obtained results can be summarized as follows:

(1) This alloy had lower density and higher melting temperature than that of equiatomic alloy. (2) The XRD result showed the BCC solid solution as the major phase with minor Laves phase, which was in good agreement with the results of empirical parameters and CALPHAD. (3) The alloy had a typical dendritic structure consists of dendrites enriched with higher-melting-temperature elements (W and Mo), interdendrites enriched with other elements and the Laves phase enriched with Cr and Ti inside the interdendrite regions. (4) The measured lattice parameter and density of the alloy (3.114 Å and 7.48 g/cm 3 ) were approximately close to the calculated values. However, the measured hardness was found to be 511 kg/ mm2 which was significantly higher (about four times) than the calculated hardness value.

figure.head: Fig. 7 (
figure.figDesc: Fig. 7(a and b) shows the XRD patterns of the W 10 Mo 27 Cr 21 Ti 22 Al 20 alloy composition in powder mixture and as-cast states. The diffraction peaks of individual elements W, Mo, Cr, Ti, Al are clearly observed in powder mixture pattern. The XRD pattern of as-cast W 10 Mo 27 Cr 21- Ti 22 Al 20 HEA illustrates the formation of BCC solid-solution phase (close to the Mo peaks with ICDD Card 00-042-1120) as a major phase with minor Laves phase corresponding to Cr 2 Ti (ICDD Card 00-049-1716).The lattice parameter of BCC phase in this alloy was also determined to be 3.144 Å by the Bragg's law[57]. This value was close to the calculated value of 3.153 Å by the rule of mixtures (a ave = ∑ x i a i )[32,[58][59][60]. The XRD result is in good agreement with the results from the both empirical parameters and CALPHAD methods, which predicted the formation of solid solution as major phase.SEM backscattered electron (BSE) image of the as-cast W 10 Mo 27 Cr 21 Ti 22 Al 20 RHEA is shown in Fig.8. figure.head: Fig. 9 .
figure.figDesc: Fig. 9. SEM BSE image of the selected region for RHEA (a) and corresponding EDS line scanning of Mo (b), W (c), Al (d), Ti (e) and Cr(f).

Fig. 10. The yield strength, σ 0.2 , (i.e., σ 0.2 is defined as the stress at ε = 0.2%) the maximum strength, σ max , and the fracture strain, ε f of the W 10 Mo 27 Cr 21 Ti 22 Al 20 RHEA at room temperature are 1245 MPa, 1310Mpa and 7.7%, respectively. At 600 • C, σ 0.2 and σ max decrease to 510Mpa and 605Mpa, and the alloy fracture occurs at about 16.4% strain. An increase in the test temperature to 1000 • C resulted in a further decrease of σ 0.2 and σ max to 201Mpa and 242Mpa, respectively.

figure.head: Fig. 10 .
figure.figDesc: Fig. 10. The compressive true stress-strain curves of W 10 Mo 27 Cr 21 Ti 22 Al 20 RHEA at different temperatures.

The alloy exhibited high yield strengths of 1245, 510, 201 and 105 at RT, 600 • C, 1000 • C and 1200 • C, respectively and no fracture occurred at high temperature (1000 • C and 1200 • C).
